name: Chlorine; chlor-alkali electrolysis; at plant
description: This unit process represents the production of 1 kg of electrolysis outputs which includes chlorine, sodium hydrozide, and hydrogen. This dataset was developed for chlorine use in PVC manufacturing. This process represents all chlorine produced by the suspension grade PVC resin manufacturers in the United States. Both membrane and diaphragm cell technologies are used, with membrane cells being the more common technology. The studied system includes all processes involved in the chloralkali electrolysis production process, including incoming transport. Mass allocation is used to allocated inputs and outputs among the three products: chlorine, sodium hydroxide, and hydrogen.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This data represents operations for the 2022 calendar year.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This data represents six manufacturing sites located in Texas and Louisiana.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription:
This process represents the chloralkali process used to produce chlorine for the use in suspension grade PVC resin. Both membrane and diaphragm cell technologies are used, with membrane cells being the more common technology. Co-products include hydrogen and sodium hydroxide. Mass allocation was used to determine the impacts of each co-product.

In the chlor-alkali process, a brine solution (aqueous sodium chloride) undergoes electrolysis to produce chlorine gas, hydrogen gas, and sodium hydroxide. Commercially, two main types of electrolytic cells are used for the chlor-alkali process: diaphragm cells and membrane cells. Membrane cells were developed more recently and are the most commonly used process today. While the treatment of the chlorine and hydrogen gases from processes using both cells are similar, with membrane cells, the sodium hydroxide can be more easily concentrated with less energy.

Several chlor-alkali facilities utilize cogeneration as a method of producing steam and electricity. Cogeneration is the simultaneous generation of electricity and steam. Within the chlor-alkali plants, electricity, natural gas, hydrogen, water, and sulfuric acid are inputs for the cogeneration process. Based on plant data collected on the cogeneration process at two chlor-alkali plants, the output energy is 49% steam and 51% electricity. This process was assumed to be the same across chlor-alkali plants.
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: Data was collected from four manufacturers which represent 100% of the S-PVC resin produced in the US in 2022. A total of six facilities provided their data for 2022 and the LCI was developed using mass allocation. Data was reviewed and verified by each of the four companies. Mass allocation is used to allocate inputs and outputs to the coproducts produced within the chlor-alkali process. The hydrogen produced as a coproduct is used as an onsite fuel or as a fuel within a downstream process to produce the S-PVC resin. The cogeneration process of electricity and steam is similar across the chlor-alkali plants to produce S-PVC resin. The cogeneration process was analyzed based off of inputs and outputs provided by two sites and assumed to be consistent across all sites and companies. The cogeneration process produces 51% electricity and 49% steam. Emissions to water and air were considered within the scope of this study and were accounted for based off of quantities in annual emissions reporting from each company. Data validation was performed through mass balances.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
The following cut-off criteria was used throughout the study. Processes whose total contribution to the final result, with respect to their mass and in relation to all considered impact categories, is less than 1% can be neglected. The sum of the neglected processes may not exceed 5% by mass and by 5% of the considered impact categories. Construction of capital equipment, maintenance of operation and support equipment, and human labor and employee commute are all excluded from this life cycle assessment. This assessment is cradle-to-gate and excludes any processes downstream of the manufacturer.
No other known processes within the system boundary were excluded. All data was provided by the manufacturers and reviewed by the manufacturers again after the results had been calculated to ensure completeness. The mass balance for this process was calculated.
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: Data was collected from four manufacturers which represent 100% of the S-PVC resin produced in the US in 2022.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: A weighted average was calculated from the primary data collected from the four manufacturers (six plants) of S-PVC in the US.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The system boundary is cradle-to-gate and includes the use of raw materials entering the facilities, the transportation to get raw and supporting materials to the manufacturing facilities, and the processing inputs and outputs to the electrolysis process. Construction of capital equipment, maintenance of operation and support equipment, and human labor and employee commute are all excluded from this life cycle assessment. Data was collected from four S-PVC manufacturers (6 plants). Uncertainty was not calculated.

sources.name: Sustainable Solutions Corporation (2024) Suspension Grade PVC Resin Life Cycle Assessment

processDocumentation.intendedApplication:
Situation C1 - Accounting, with system-external interactions - The intended application is a purely descriptive accounting / documentation of the analyzed system including existing interactions with other systems in the LCI model.

The target audience of this model includes LCA practitioners, industry, and the general public. A full inventory of environmental flows are included; thus this unit process can be used for a full range of LCIA impact categories. The original study results were analyzed using the TRACI LCIA factors. These data are an update to the previously published dataset from 2021.

These data are intended to be used as an average dataset accepted by the North American plastics/chemical industry.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: This process was developed as part of the Vinyl Institute's Suspension Grade PVC Resin Life Cycle Assessment.

publication.name: Sustainable Solutions Corporation (2024) Suspension Grade PVC Resin Life Cycle Assessment

processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription:

The user is granted the right, without any fee or cost, to use, copy, modify, alter, enhance and distribute these Data for any purpose whatsoever, provided that this entire notice appears in all copies of the Data. Any modification, alteration or enhancement of these data shall be identified and documented by the user. Further, the user agrees to credit the DOE/NREL/Alliance in any publication that results from the use of these Data. The names DOE/NREL/Alliance, however, may not be used in any advertising or publicity to endorse or promote any products or commercial entities unless specific written permission is obtained from DOE/NREL/Alliance. The user also understands that DOE/NREL/Alliance is not obligated to provide the user with any support, consulting, training or assistance of any kind with regard to the use of these Data or to provide the user with any updates, revisions or new versions of these Data.

IN NO EVENT SHALL THE GOVERNMENT OR DOE/NREL/ALLIANCE BE LIABLE FOR ANY SPECIAL, INDIRECT OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES OR ANY DAMAGES WHATSOEVER, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO CLAIMS ASSOCIATED WITH THE LOSS OF DATA OR PROFITS, WHICH MAY RESULT FROM AN ACTION IN CONTRACT, NEGLIGENCE OR OTHER TORTIOUS CLAIM THAT ARISES OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE ACCESS, USE OR PERFORMANCE OF THESE DATA.
